claim_text: DPP4i + Met demonstrated a non-significant lower incidence of CV events in comparison to TZD + Met and SU + Met.
The study used the Korean National Health Insurance Service database from December 1, 2008, to December 31, 2013.
The combination of DPP4i + Met revealed a comparable mean reduction in HbA1c levels to the glinides (Gli) + Met combination.
The study found no significant increased risk of total CVDs in the DPP-4 inhibitors group compared to the glimepiride group.
DPP4i + Met had a greater mean HbA1c reduction compared to sulfonylureas (SU) + Met and thiazolidinedione (TZD) + Met.
Patients with a history of visit for CVDs had a decreased risk of hospitalization for CVDs in the DPP-4 inhibitors group compared to the glimepiride group.
The combination of DPP4i + Met was efficacious and had a well-tolerated safety profile compared with other traditional OADs.
Patients with more than 2.5 years of type 2 diabetes had a decreased risk of hospitalization for CVDs in the DPP-4 inhibitors group compared to the glimepiride group.
Sixty-two trials were included in the analysis for this systematic literature review and network meta-analysis.
DPP-4 inhibitors did not increase cardiovascular risk regardless of CVD history and diabetes duration.
Alogliptin showed a statistically significant benefit in monotherapy compared to placebo.
Alogliptin had the highest rating among DPP-4 inhibitors for all subgroups based on SUCRA.
The study included 38 randomized clinical trials (RCTs) analyzing DPP-4 inhibitors and their combination with metformin.
Alogliptin was found to be superior in monotherapy compared to other DPP-4 inhibitors, including combination with metformin.
The study's endpoint was the percentage of patients achieving target HbA1c level.
The United States led in publication output for DPP-4 inhibitors and cardiovascular outcomes studies.
Harvard University and the University of Toronto were identified as leading institutions in DPP-4 inhibitor research.
The most influential journals for DPP-4 inhibitors and cardiovascular outcomes studies are Cardiovascular Diabetology and Diabetes Obesity & Metabolism.
Darren K. McGuire was the most prolific author in DPP-4 inhibitor research studies.
Heart failure is a frequently occurring keyword in DPP-4 inhibitor and cardiovascular outcomes studies, indicating a strong focus on cardiovascular safety.
DPP-4 inhibitors can reduce daily insulin requirements, especially for patients with a BMI < 25 kg/m² and diabetes duration < 3 years.
DPP-4 inhibitors can reduce postprandial blood glucose, especially for patients with a BMI < 25 kg/m² and diabetes duration < 3 years.
DPP-4 inhibitors may transiently enhance β-cell function in patients with T1DM.
The efficacy of DPP-4 inhibitors as adjunct therapy for T1DM is not sustained over time, resulting in only a transient improvement in HbA1c.
DPP-4 inhibitors are considered safe for use as adjunct therapy to insulin in patients with T1DM, based on the safety outcomes observed in this study.
DPP-4 inhibitors have emerged as a popular class of glucose-lowering agents.
The impact of DPP-4 inhibitors on heart failure outcomes in patients with diabetes remains contentious, with conflicting evidence from clinical trials and observational studies.
Clinical trials such as SAVOR-TIMI 53, EXAMINE, and TECOS are evaluated to provide a comprehensive analysis of DPP-4 inhibitors' effects.
Some trials suggest an increased risk of HF hospitalizations with specific DPP-4 inhibitors (e.g., saxagliptin), while others report neutral effects.
Discrepancies in outcomes related to patient demographics, HF phenotype, and comorbid conditions influence DPP-4 inhibitors' risk–benefit profile.
Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i), Dipeptyl Peptidase-4 inhibitors (DPP-4i) and Glucagon-Like Peptide-1 agonists (GLP-1a) effectively reduce HbA1c levels.
Their long-term cardiovascular effects have been tested against placebo, but the comparative efficacy of individual drug types is unclear.
A network meta-analysis was conducted to compare the efficacy of SGLT2i, DPP-4i and GLP-1a for reducing cardiovascular outcomes.
Empagliflozin and liraglutide reduced cardiovascular mortality compared to control (RR 0.63; 95% CI 0.51-0.79; P < 0.001).
This study provides evidence to support clinical decisions in treatment of type 2 diabetes.
Trial Evaluating Cardiovascular Outcomes with Sitagliptin (TECOS) assessed the cardiovascular safety of sitagliptin versus placebo.
The TECOS trial found that sitagliptin is noninferior to placebo in terms of cardiovascular outcomes for patients with type 2 diabetes and CV disease.
Merck & Co., Inc., was the Sponsor of the TECOS trial.
The TIMI Study Group re-adjudicated a prespecified set of originally adjudicated events based on feedback from the FDA for TECOS.
The re-adjudication was conducted to reassess the cardiovascular safety of sitagliptin based on feedback from FDA.
DPP-4 inhibitors improved the pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) in preclinical trials.
The additional use of DPP-4 inhibitors resulted in a greater decrease in glycated hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels compared to insulin monotherapy.
DPP-4 inhibitors showed a small decrease in postprandial glucose or insulin consumption.
Meta-analysis pooled data from 5 randomized controlled trials.
Existing studies do not strongly support the positive effects of DPP-4 inhibitors in clinical practice.
SGLT2 inhibitors reduce HbA1c levels significantly more than other treatments.
Metformin is a first-line therapy for T2DM due to its safety, efficacy, and affordability.
DPP-4 inhibitors are weight-neutral and well-tolerated compared to other treatments.
SGLT2 inhibitors provide additional cardiovascular benefits, reducing major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) and chronic kidney disease progression.
Insulin is the most potent glucose-lowering agent but carries a higher risk of hypoglycemia and weight gain compared to other treatments.
The model was developed using longitudinal data from 11,234 patients (10 linagliptin, 15 sitagliptin trials).
The model adequately described the observations.
Simulations showed both linagliptin 5 mg and sitagliptin 100 mg reduced HbA1c by 0.81% (placebo-adjusted) at week 24.
The final model described HbA1c levels as function of time, dose, baseline HbA1c, washout status/duration and ethnicity.
This study demonstrates the use of longitudinal MBMA in the field of diabetes treatment.
Grace period was not reported in 5 (35.7%) studies and ranged from 0 days to 180 days when reported.
Carry-over was not reported in 10 studies (71.4%).
Lag effect was not reported in nine (71.4%) studies and ranged from 0 days to 180 days when reported.
No studies conducted sensitivity analyses examining the effects of these assumptions on study findings.
Predominant biases were inadequate follow-up time, comparability of cohorts, prevalent use, and lag time bias.
Eighteen RCTs involving 6,493 patients with an average follow-up of 32 weeks were identified and analyzed.
DPP-4i plus insulin showed greater reduction in HbA1c than insulin alone (WMD -0.52%, 95% CI -0.61 to -0.43; P < 0.00001).
This updated systematic review and meta-analysis aimed to evaluate the effect of DPP-4i in combination with insulin on HbA1c in T2DM patients.
The primary endpoint was the absolute change of HbA1c from baseline.
DPP-4i plus insulin can significantly lower HbA1c levels in T2DM patients compared to use of insulin alone.
The study was conducted using the National Health Insurance Research Database.
Patients with type 2 diabetes and advanced chronic kidney disease were identified during the period from 2011 to 2015.
The primary outcome of the study was the composite renal outcome.
DPP4is reduced the risks of hospitalized hypoglycemia and all-cause death compared to sulfonylureas.
The study concluded that DPP4is may be preferred for patients with type 2 diabetes and advanced chronic kidney disease, and regular monitoring of cardiac function is crucial.
SGLT-2 inhibitors achieved greater reductions in HbA1c compared to DPP-4 inhibitors.
SGLT-2 inhibitors showed greater reductions in body weight compared to DPP-4 inhibitors.
In North America and Europe, SGLT-2 inhibitors had significant reductions in HbA1c and FPG levels compared to Asia.
SGLT-2 inhibitors are associated with an increased incidence of genital infections (OR 4.49; 95% CI: 2.96, 6.83; p=0.000).
SGLT-2 inhibitors are associated with a higher incidence of pollakiuria (OR 2.24; 95% CI: 1.05, 4.79; p=0.037).
Ertugliflozin is a new sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 inhibitor (SGLT2i) for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

The primary objective was to indirectly compare ertugliflozin to other SGLT2is in patient populations with inadequately controlled glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c > 7.0%) and previously treated with either diet/exercise, metformin alone or metformin plus a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitor (DPP4i).
Bayesian network meta-analysis was used to synthesize evidence.
In patients uncontrolled on diet/exercise, the efficacy of ertugliflozin 5 mg monotherapy was not significantly different from that of other low-dose SGLT2is in terms of HbA1c reduction.
As add-on therapy to metformin, ertugliflozin 5 mg was more effective in lowering HbA1c than dapagliflozin 5 mg.
Adams KK, et al. Re-evaluating aztreonam and ceftazidime hypersensitivity: fraternal not identical twins
Baldolli A, et al. Tolerance of BNT162b2 mRNA COVI-19 vaccine in patients with a medical history of COVID-19 disease: A case control study
Furuya-Kanamori L, et al. Comparison of immunogenicity and safety of licensed Japanese encephalitis vaccines: A systematic review and network meta-analysis
Lin DS, et al. Major adverse cardiovascular and limb events in patients with diabetes treated with GLP-1 receptor agonists vs DPP-4 inhibitors
Petrelli F, et al. Risk of Infection with Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
Forty-five out of 71 subjects in the sitagliptin group and 41 out of 62 subjects in the conventional group filled out the QOL questionnaire at week 104.
The DTR-QOL7 score at week 104 was significantly increased from baseline in the sitagliptin group, while that in the conventional group was not changed.
Change in HbA1c was negatively associated with change in score.
The study population consisted of 71 subjects in the sitagliptin group and 62 subjects in the conventional group who were treated with insulin.
ClinicalTrialRegistration: UMIN000007396 and Funding: Mitsubishi Tanabe Pharma Co., Ono Pharmaceutical Co., and Novo Nordisk.
The combination of GLP-1 RAs, SGLT-2i, and DPP-4i can significantly reduce HbA1c levels.
The combination of GLP-1 RAs, SGLT-2i, and DPP-4i can significantly reduce fasting plasma glucose levels.
The combination of GLP-1 RAs can significantly reduce body weight in Type 2 diabetes mellitus patients.
The dose of basic insulin is reduced after the combination use of GLP-1 RAs.
GLP-1 RAs increase the risk of hypoglycemia compared to placebo.
A study evaluated the clinical and metabolic profile in a type 1 diabetes cohort.
The study included 20 type 1 Diabetes subjects above 18 years of age with poorly controlled glycemia (HbA1c 7 to 10%).
The study used sitagliptin and dapagliflozin as adjuvant therapies in combination with insulin.
Sitagliptin did not reduce fasting plasma glucagon levels when added to dapagliflozin.
Dapagliflozin increased the median ketone (beta-hydroxybutyrate) levels compared to baseline.
